featured.text: Often considered as representing the circle of life, hoops featured prominently in the ritual dances of Native Americans.
The hula hoop gained international popularity in the late 1950s, when a plastic version was successfully marketed by California’s Wham-O toy company.
Although the term did not emerge until the 18th century, toy hoops twirled around the waist, limbs, or neck can be traced back to ancient times.
Their hoops, often made of metal, were not merely toys for Greek children but served as exercise devices as well.
Twenty-five million plastic hoops were sold in less than four months.

other.text: The craze for hoops even resulted in dislocated backs and heart attacks, according to medical records.
Hoops spun their way through the cultures of pre-colonial America as well.
Dancers used small reed hoops as symbolic representations of animals such as eagles or snakes.
The hula hoop “fad” is still going strong today.
Though no hoops were used, the movements of the ritual dances looked very similar to those in hooping.
With very rapid movements, they used the hoops to construct the symbolic forms around their bodies.
Thus “hula” and “hoop” came together, resulting in the term “hula hooping.”
Why did Wham-O start making hula hoops?
As early as 1000 BC, Egyptian children played with hoop toys of dried grapevine.
Hoop rolling was also popular in ancient Greece.
In the 14th century, hoops were popular as a form of recreation in Great Britain.
